Title:
Phylogenetic analysis of the Asian Cyprinid genus Danio
(Teleostei, Cyprinidae).
Journal: Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
Abstract:
A phylogenetic analysis of Danio (sensu lato), based on 38
morphological characters, shows that Danio, as recognized until now, is
paraphyletic. Danio is restricted to species previously recognized as
the “Danio dangila species group,” including D. dangila, Danio rerio,
Danio nigrofasciatus, and Danio albolineatus. Those species share an “A
stripe” on the anal-fin rays, an anterior lateral extension ventrally on
the dentary, two or more pigment stripes on the caudal-fin rays and
greatly enlarged lamellar nasal. Esomus is the sister group of Danio.
Remaining Danio (sensu lato) species are referred to Deuario,
characterized by a short and wide premaxillary ascending process with a
minute apophysis contacting the kinethmoid, a short max-Uary barbel, a
“P stripe” extending onto the median caudal-fin rays, and infraorbital 5
not or only slightly reduced. Dmario includes the species Dmario
malabaricus, Deuario Kakhienensis, Dmario deuario, Deuario
chrysotaeniatus, Deuario maetaengensis, Dmario interruptus, and Deuario
apogon. The sister group of Dmario is a clade composed of Znlecypis and
Chela. The well-known genus Brachydanio becomes a junior synonym of
Danio (sensu stricto). The phylogenetic relationships of small Danielike
species Sundadanio axelrodi, Danionella translucida, Danio
erythromicron, and Microrasbota rubescens remain unresolved.
